title: Joshua Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who did Joshua send from Shittim to spy out Jericho?
questions.correctAnswer: Two men
questions.explanation: Joshua sent out two men to spy secretly, as stated in Joshua 2:1.

questions.question: Where did the two spies lodge when they came to Jericho?
questions.correctAnswer: A harlot's house
questions.explanation: The two men came into the house of a harlot named Rahab and lodged there (Joshua 2:1).

questions.question: What was the name of the woman who hid the spies?
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab
questions.explanation: The woman who hid the spies was named Rahab, according to Joshua 2:1.

questions.question: What did the king of Jericho command Rahab to do?
options: Bring forth the men who came to her house
questions.correctAnswer: Bring forth the men who came to her house
questions.explanation: The king sent to Rahab saying to bring out the men who came to her house (Joshua 2:3).

questions.question: Where did Rahab hide the two men?
options: On the roof under flax stalks
questions.correctAnswer: On the roof under flax stalks
questions.explanation: Rahab hid them on the roof under stalks of flax laid in order (Joshua 2:6).

questions.question: True or False: The men escaped Jericho by going out at sunset when it was dark.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The men went out about the time of shutting the gate, when it was dark (Joshua 2:5).

questions.question: What did Rahab say she did not know when asked about the men?
questions.correctAnswer: Where they came from
questions.explanation: Rahab said she did not know whence the men were (Joshua 2:4).

questions.question: According to Rahab, who has given the land to Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Rahab said she knew the LORD had given them the land (Joshua 2:9).

questions.question: Which two kings did Rahab say Israel had destroyed on the other side of Jordan?
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon and Og
questions.explanation: Rahab mentioned the two kings Sihon and Og whom Israel utterly destroyed (Joshua 2:10).

questions.question: What color was the thread Rahab was told to bind in her window?
questions.correctAnswer: Scarlet
questions.explanation: Rahab was instructed to bind a scarlet thread in the window (Joshua 2:18).

questions.question: True or False: Rahab asked the spies to swear to show kindness to her father's house.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Rahab requested a sworn promise to show kindness to her father's house (Joshua 2:12).

questions.question: How did Rahab lower the spies from her house to help them escape?
options: By a cord through the window
questions.correctAnswer: By a cord through the window
questions.explanation: She let them down by a cord through the window (Joshua 2:15).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rahab told the men to hide in the ______ for three days until the pursuers returned.
questions.correctAnswer: mountain
questions.explanation: Rahab advised the men to hide in the mountain for three days (Joshua 2:16).

questions.question: True or False: The pursuers found the spies after searching all the way.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The pursuers searched but found them not (Joshua 2:22).

questions.question: What did the spies report to Joshua about the inhabitants of the land?
options: They do not know about Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They faint because of us
questions.explanation: The spies told Joshua the inhabitants faint because of Israel (Joshua 2:24).

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is fearful about upcoming challenges and asks for encouragement. Based on Joshua 2, what biblical truth about faith and God's power would you share?
options: God has already given us the land and causes fear among our enemies
We must rely only on our own strength and plans
Fear is a sign that God is not with us
God's promises depend on our perfect performance
questions.correctAnswer: God has already given us the land and causes fear among our enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:9-11 shows Rahab acknowledging that the LORD has given the land to Israel and that their enemies are fainthearted because of them, teaching us to trust God's power and promises.

questions.question: How does Rahab's action in hiding the spies teach us about integrity and courage in difficult circumstances?
options: She risked her life by hiding them rather than betraying them
She immediately betrayed the spies to protect herself
She ignored the spies and did nothing
She reported the spies to the king without hesitation
questions.correctAnswer: She risked her life by hiding them rather than betraying them
questions.explanation: In Joshua 2:4-6, Rahab hides the men despite the danger from the king's pursuit, demonstrating integrity and courageous obedience.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with trusting God's plan. Based on Joshua 2, what assurance can you offer about God's faithfulness?
options: God has already delivered the land into our hands and causes fear among enemies
God's promises are uncertain and depend on human strength
We have to fight all battles alone without God's help
God only helps those who never make mistakes
questions.correctAnswer: God has already delivered the land into our hands and causes fear among enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:24 emphasizes that the LORD has delivered the land and caused the inhabitants to faint, assuring believers of God's faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Rahab's request for protection for her family teach us about the importance of interceding for our loved ones?
options: She asked the spies to swear kindness to her father's household for their safety
She ignored her family and sought only her own safety
She demanded the spies abandon their mission to save her family
She refused to trust the spies and hid her family herself
questions.correctAnswer: She asked the spies to swear kindness to her father's household for their safety
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:12-13 shows Rahab interceding for her family’s lives, illustrating the biblical value of praying and standing in faith for our families.

questions.question: What does the scarlet cord in Rahab’s window symbolize about obedience and protection in God's plan?
options: It was a sign to save those inside who obeyed the instruction
It was a decoration with no particular meaning
It marked her house for destruction
It was a code to betray the spies
questions.correctAnswer: It was a sign to save those inside who obeyed the instruction
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:18-21 explains the scarlet line as a token of protection for Rahab’s household, teaching obedience and trust in God's instructions bring safety.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise honesty for personal safety. What lesson does Joshua 2 teach about honesty and trust in God's protection?
options: Rahab honestly told the king she did not know the spies’ whereabouts, trusting God's protection
Rahab lied to the king and betrayed the spies immediately
Rahab avoided facing the king by fleeing the city
Rahab falsely accused others to protect herself
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab honestly told the king she did not know the spies’ whereabouts, trusting God's protection
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:4 shows Rahab’s careful but truthful response to the king, illustrating that integrity combined with faith is crucial.

questions.question: How does the spies’ promise to Rahab about kindness exemplify the biblical principle of keeping one’s word?
options: They vowed to protect her and her family if she kept their mission secret
They made no promises and left her to her own fate
They promised riches but did not intend to keep it
They demanded payment for their protection
questions.correctAnswer: They vowed to protect her and her family if she kept their mission secret
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:14 and 17-20 shows the spies making a solemn oath to Rahab, teaching the importance of honesty and faithfulness to promises.

questions.question: True or False: The spies were careless and revealed their mission openly in Jericho.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:1 states the spies were sent secretly to view Jericho, indicating careful and strategic obedience to God's plan.

questions.question: What does Rahab’s acknowledgment of God’s sovereignty teach us about humility and faith in daily life?
options: She recognized the LORD as God in heaven and on earth, showing humility and faith
She ignored God and relied on her own strength
She claimed to be equal to God
questions.correctAnswer: She recognized the LORD as God in heaven and on earth, showing humility and faith
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:11 reveals Rahab’s faith in God's sovereignty, teaching believers humility and trust in God's supremacy.

questions.question: How does the spies’ instruction to Rahab on hiding and waiting show biblical wisdom in perseverance and timing?
options: They told her to hide and stay safe for three days until pursuers returned
They told her to leave immediately and run away
They advised her to confront the pursuers
They instructed her to betray them after three days
questions.correctAnswer: They told her to hide and stay safe for three days until pursuers returned
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:16-17 demonstrates the wisdom of patience and cautious perseverance, trusting God’s timing.

questions.question: True or False: The king of Jericho immediately captured the spies after entering Rahab’s house.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:7 and 22 show the spies escaped successfully and the pursuers found them not, exemplifying God's protection.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of opposition. How does Joshua 2 teach about God’s power over earthly rulers and fears?
options: The inhabitants faint because of the Israelites' God, showing His power over human fears
Earthly rulers are always stronger than God's people
Fear is an indication God is not present
Opposition means God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants faint because of the Israelites' God, showing His power over human fears
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:9-11 describes how the terror of Israel caused the hearts of the inhabitants to melt, teaching that God's power overcomes fear.

questions.question: How does the story of Rahab emphasize the importance of witness and evangelism in God’s plan?
options: Rahab's faith and actions led to her salvation and protection for her family
Rahab kept silent and isolated herself from God's people
Rahab opposed the Israelites and their God
Rahab refused to believe in the God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab's faith and actions led to her salvation and protection for her family
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:12-21 shows Rahab’s faith and cooperation with God’s plan, illustrating how personal witness and faith impact salvation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua sent two men to spy secretly from the camp at ______ to view the land of Jericho.
questions.correctAnswer: Shittim
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:1 states that Joshua sent two men from Shittim to spy out Jericho, highlighting obedience to God's directive.

questions.question: How does Rahab’s example teach us about trusting God despite our past and current circumstances?
options: Despite being a harlot, she demonstrated faith that God delivers and protects
She was rejected because of her past and could not receive God's help
She tried to earn God's favor without faith
She relied on her own power to survive
questions.correctAnswer: Despite being a harlot, she demonstrated faith that God delivers and protects
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:1 and 9-11 show Rahab's faith in God despite her background, teaching us God’s grace and mercy extend to all who trust Him.

questions.question: What lesson about spiritual fellowship and protection can we learn from the spies’ promise involving Rahab’s household?
options: Those who remain inside Rahab’s house under the scarlet cord will be protected
Protection is guaranteed regardless of one's actions
Only the spies themselves would be protected
Rahab’s household was left vulnerable without any promise
questions.correctAnswer: Those who remain inside Rahab’s house under the scarlet cord will be protected
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:18-19 teaches that spiritual fellowship and obedience bring protection, as those inside Rahab's house were promised safety.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 2.

questions.question: What was the primary mission of the two men sent out by Joshua from Shittim?
options: To spy secretly and view the land, especially Jericho
To negotiate a peace treaty with Jericho
To establish a covenant with Rahab
questions.correctAnswer: To spy secretly and view the land, especially Jericho
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:1 states that Joshua sent two men to spy secretly and view the land, specifically Jericho.

questions.question: How did Rahab hide the two Israelite spies sent by Joshua?
options: She hid them on the roof among stalks of flax
She hid them in a secret cave outside the city
She concealed them in a grain storage room
questions.correctAnswer: She hid them on the roof among stalks of flax
questions.explanation: According to Joshua 2:6, Rahab hid the men on the roof with stalks of flax laid in order.

questions.question: Which kings of the Amorites are mentioned by Rahab as having been destroyed by the Israelites?
questions.correctAnswer: Sihon and Og
questions.explanation: Rahab references Sihon and Og, the Amorite kings defeated by Israel, in Joshua 2:10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the scarlet thread that Rahab was instructed to bind in her window?
options: It served as a sign to spare her household during Jericho's conquest
It symbolized the blood of the Passover lamb
It represented the covenant between Israel and Jericho
It was a mark of social status in Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: It served as a sign to spare her household during Jericho's conquest
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:18-21 explain that the scarlet thread in Rahab's window was a token to protect her family from harm.

questions.question: Rahab's declaration that 'the LORD your God, he is God in heaven above, and in earth beneath' is an example of what theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty and universal lordship
questions.explanation: In Joshua 2:11, Rahab acknowledges God's supreme authority over all realms, indicating divine sovereignty.

questions.question: Which cultural practice is reflected in the spies asking Rahab for a 'true token' to ensure protection for her family?
options: Covenantal oath and the giving of a pledge
questions.correctAnswer: Covenantal oath and the giving of a pledge
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:12-14 shows the spies making a covenantal oath with Rahab, a common ancient Near Eastern practice to guarantee safety.

questions.question: In what way does Rahab's protection of the spies foreshadow New Testament themes?
options: Her faith and actions prefigure salvation by faith and inclusion of Gentiles
Her story predicts the destruction of the temple
She represents the archetype of a prophetess
Her house becomes the first church
questions.correctAnswer: Her faith and actions prefigure salvation by faith and inclusion of Gentiles
questions.explanation: Rahab's faith and protection of Israelite spies (Joshua 2:9-14) is cited in Hebrews 11:31 and James 2:25 as an example of faith leading to salvation, highlighting Gentile inclusion.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of Rahab's house being 'upon the town wall' in Joshua 2:15?
options: It symbolizes a liminal space between enemy and ally
It indicates she was a city official
It shows she was isolated from the community
It implies her house was a fortress
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a liminal space between enemy and ally
questions.explanation: Rahab's location on the city wall (Joshua 2:15) situates her literally and figuratively at the boundary between Jericho and Israel, emphasizing themes of transition and covenant.

questions.question: True or False: The pursuers who followed the spies successfully found them on the mountain after they left Rahab's house.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:22 states the pursuers sought the spies but did not find them.

questions.question: What was the spies’ report to Joshua after returning from their mission?
options: The LORD has given all the land into our hands and the inhabitants are faint because of us
The city of Jericho is well-fortified and impossible to conquer
The inhabitants are united and ready to fight
Rahab betrayed us to the king
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD has given all the land into our hands and the inhabitants are faint because of us
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:24 records the spies' confident report that God has delivered the land and its inhabitants are fearful.

questions.question: Which event mentioned by Rahab in Joshua 2:10-11 connects to Israel’s Exodus narrative?
options: The drying up of the Red Sea waters
The giving of the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: The drying up of the Red Sea waters
questions.explanation: Rahab references God's miraculous parting of the Red Sea during the Exodus as evidence of His power (Joshua 2:10).

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'harlot' in Joshua 2:1 imply about Rahab's social status, and how does this affect the narrative's theological message?
options: She was a woman of low social standing, highlighting God's grace to the marginalized
She was a priestess, signifying religious corruption
She was a wealthy merchant, indicating political influence
She was a royal consort, symbolizing alliance
questions.correctAnswer: She was a woman of low social standing, highlighting God's grace to the marginalized
questions.explanation: The term 'harlot' (Joshua 2:1) suggests Rahab's marginalized status, making her faith and inclusion in Israel's story a powerful example of divine grace.

questions.question: How does the narrative structure of Joshua 2 reflect elements of chiasmus?
options: The story centers on Rahab’s covenant with the spies, framed by the spies entering and exiting Jericho
The spies are captured, then released, then captured again
Rahab’s house is described twice in the beginning and end
The narrative repeats the same dialogue in reverse order
questions.correctAnswer: The story centers on Rahab’s covenant with the spies, framed by the spies entering and exiting Jericho
questions.explanation: Joshua 2’s literary structure frames Rahab's covenant (verses 12-21) between the spies' secret entry and their escape, a chiastic pattern emphasizing the covenant's importance.

questions.question: What was the cultural and military significance of 'the fords of the Jordan' mentioned in Joshua 2:7 in the spies' escape route?
options: Fords were strategic crossing points vital for invading armies
They were sacred sites where sacrifices were performed
They marked the boundary of Jericho’s control
They were used as marketplaces for trade
questions.correctAnswer: Fords were strategic crossing points vital for invading armies
questions.explanation: The Jordan fords (Joshua 2:7) were crucial for military movement, enabling the spies to cross into Israelite territory safely.

questions.question: Which New Testament book explicitly refers to Rahab’s faith and actions as an example of justified faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Hebrews
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:31 references Rahab’s faith and her protection of the spies, connecting Joshua 2’s narrative to New Testament theology.

questions.question: True or False: Rahab's protection of the spies was contingent upon their promise to deliver her family alive when Israel conquered the land.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 2:12-14 records Rahab requesting a promise for her family’s safety, which the spies agree to as a condition of her aid.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological truth about God's sovereignty is revealed through Rahab's confession to the spies?
options: The LORD is God in heaven above and on earth beneath
God is limited to the land of Canaan
God is unknown to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is God in heaven above and on earth beneath
questions.explanation: Rahab acknowledges God's universal sovereignty in Joshua 2:11, which aligns with scriptures like Psalm 115:3, Daniel 4:35, Colossians 1:16-17, and Revelation 4:11, affirming that God reigns over all creation.

questions.question: What does Rahab's act of hiding the spies symbolize in Christian theology?
questions.correctAnswer: Faith and protection by grace
questions.explanation: Rahab's hiding of the spies (Joshua 2:4,6) demonstrates faith leading to salvation by God’s grace, typifying Hebrews 11:31 and James 2:25, showing that faith expresses itself in action and results in God’s deliverance.

questions.question: Which doctrine is most clearly illustrated by the spies' promise to Rahab upon her protection of them?
questions.correctAnswer: Covenant faithfulness and grace
questions.explanation: The promise to Rahab (Joshua 2:14) reflects God's covenant faithfulness and grace, emphasizing God's commitment to those who show faith, consistent with 2 Samuel 7:14, Isaiah 54:10, Romans 11:29, and Ephesians 2:8-9.

questions.question: How does Rahab’s recognition of Israel’s God reveal the doctrine of revelation?
options: God reveals Himself to all nations
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals Himself to all nations
questions.explanation: Rahab's knowledge of the LORD's deeds (Joshua 2:9-10) shows God’s self-revelation beyond Israel, supported by Psalm 96:3, Isaiah 45:22, Acts 14:17, and Romans 1:19-20, demonstrating God’s universal disclosure of His nature and works.

questions.question: What does the scarlet cord in Rahab's window symbolize in biblical theology?
options: Salvation and protection through the blood
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation and protection through the blood
questions.explanation: The scarlet cord (Joshua 2:18,21) symbolizes salvation through blood, prefiguring the Passover lamb's blood in Exodus 12:13, the blood of Christ in Hebrews 9:12-14, and Revelation 12:11, indicating divine protection through atonement.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied by the spies’ assurance that the land will be delivered into Israel’s hands?
options: God’s promised kingdom will be established
Salvation is only a physical event
questions.correctAnswer: God’s promised kingdom will be established
questions.explanation: The spies’ confidence in deliverance (Joshua 2:24) points to the fulfillment of God's kingdom promises, consistent with Daniel 2:44, Matthew 6:10, Revelation 11:15, and Romans 14:17, anticipating God's final reign.

questions.question: How does Rahab's plea for her family’s salvation demonstrate the biblical understanding of intercessory faith?
options: Faith can intercede for others' salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Faith can intercede for others' salvation
questions.explanation: Rahab’s request to save her family (Joshua 2:12-13) shows intercessory faith, reflecting biblical examples such as Abraham’s intercession (Genesis 18:23-32), Moses (Exodus 32:11-14), and Jesus' intercession (John 17), underscoring the power of faith for others.

questions.question: What attribute of God is revealed by the terror and fear experienced by Jericho’s inhabitants?
options: God’s power to instill fear and bring judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s power to instill fear and bring judgment
questions.explanation: The fear of Israel’s God (Joshua 2:9-11) reveals His attribute of sovereign power to judge and bring terror, as seen in Exodus 15:14-16, Deuteronomy 2:25, Isaiah 8:13, and Hebrews 10:31, demonstrating God’s just authority.

questions.question: What doctrine is indicated by the spies’ instruction that Rahab must not reveal their mission under penalty of forfeiting their oath?
questions.correctAnswer: The seriousness of covenant vows
questions.explanation: The spies’ warning to Rahab (Joshua 2:20) underscores the solemnity of covenant faithfulness, consistent with Ecclesiastes 5:4-5, Numbers 30:2, Matthew 5:33-37, and Hebrews 6:16, emphasizing that oaths must be honored.

questions.question: How does the spies’ mission reflect God's providence in salvation history?
options: God orchestrates events to fulfill His promises
God is passive in human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God orchestrates events to fulfill His promises
questions.explanation: The sending of spies by Joshua (Joshua 2:1-3) shows God's providential guidance in fulfilling His covenant, paralleling Genesis 50:20, Exodus 3:7-8, Romans 8:28, and Ephesians 1:11, affirming God’s control over salvation history.

questions.question: What Christological foreshadowing is found in Rahab’s salvation and inclusion in Israel?
options: Gentile inclusion through faith in God
Exclusion of outsiders from God’s people
questions.correctAnswer: Gentile inclusion through faith in God
questions.explanation: Rahab, a Gentile, is saved by faith (Joshua 2:14, Hebrews 11:31), prefiguring the New Testament truth of Gentile inclusion in Christ (Ephesians 2:11-22, Galatians 3:28, Romans 11:17-24, Acts 10), showing salvation by faith transcends ethnic boundaries.

questions.question: What does Rahab’s house being on the city wall signify in a theological context?
options: God’s protection at the boundary of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection at the boundary of judgment
questions.explanation: Rahab’s house on the wall (Joshua 2:15) symbolizes God’s mercy at the edge of judgment, reminiscent of the Passover in Exodus 12:22, the city’s protection in Nehemiah 2:17-20, and Christ as the boundary between life and death (John 10:9), illustrating divine protection.

questions.question: How does the spies’ instruction to hide for three days relate to biblical typology?
options: Symbolizes a period of testing and deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolizes a period of testing and deliverance
questions.explanation: The three days hiding (Joshua 2:16,22) typify a time of trial before deliverance, paralleling Jonah 1:17, Jesus’ resurrection after three days (Luke 24:7), and Israel’s wilderness period, illustrating God’s faithfulness through testing.

questions.question: What does Rahab’s fear and acknowledgment of Israel’s God teach about human response to divine revelation?
options: True knowledge of God produces reverent fear and faith
Knowledge of God leads to arrogance
Divine revelation is ignored by all
Fear of God is irrelevant to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: True knowledge of God produces reverent fear and faith
questions.explanation: Rahab’s response (Joshua 2:11) shows that encountering God’s power leads to fear and faith, consistent with Proverbs 1:7, Psalm 33:8, Acts 9:31, and Hebrews 12:28, indicating reverent fear is the beginning of wisdom and faith.

questions.question: What aspect of God's justice is demonstrated by the spies’ warning about those who leave Rahab’s house?
questions.correctAnswer: Individual responsibility for one's actions
questions.explanation: The spies’ warning (Joshua 2:19) emphasizes personal responsibility, consistent with Ezekiel 18:20, Galatians 6:5, Romans 14:12, and 2 Corinthians 5:10, affirming that individuals bear consequences for their choices before God.

questions.question: How does Joshua 2 depict the interplay between human agency and divine sovereignty?
options: Human actions under God’s sovereign plan
questions.correctAnswer: Human actions under God’s sovereign plan
questions.explanation: Joshua sending spies (Joshua 2:1) and Rahab’s cooperation show human choices within God’s sovereign control, reflecting Proverbs 16:9, Isaiah 46:10, Philippians 2:12-13, and Romans 8:28, illustrating divine providence working through human decisions.
